text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Incorporated interim guidance TEGE-04-0817-0027, Interim Guidance on Cases Subject to Mandatory Review at IRM 4.81.14.5, Mandatory Review.
Incorporated interim guidance TEGE-
, Interim Guidance on Cases Mandatory Review at IRM
, Mandatory Review. Editorial changes throughout the IRM to: (cid:
) replace the term “agent” with “examiner” (cid:
) change instances of “ITG/TEB” to “TEB” because this IRM pertains to the TEB process.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This supersedes IRM 4.81.14 dated August 28, 2018. This incorporates but does not supersede interim guidance
Tax Exempt and Government Entities Government Entities and Shared Services Tax Exempt Bonds
Table of Contents
Authority: TEB’s Examination authority to resolve issues comes from its authority determine tax liability under IRC 6201.
This manual uses the following acronyms and terms.

Acronym Deﬁnition AIMS Audit Information Management System Appeals Office of Appeals Examiner TEB Revenue Agent FO Field Operations FOM Field Operations Manager ITG Indian Tribal Governments Pub 5 This publication is enclosed with 30-day letter to provide taxpayers with detailed information on their rights of appeal. RCCMS Reporting Compliance Case Man- agement System TEB Tax Exempt Bonds TLS Tax Law Specialist

) If the FOM determines help is warranted, the group manager, FOM, group manager, TLS and examiner should follow the procedures in IRM Tax Exempt Bonds Examination Program and Procedures, Technical Assis- tance and Technical Advice Requests. Note: The FOM may contact the TEB technical advisor at any time for help. Note: Consider whether the legal issue warrants tech advice. Doesn’t timely request an appeal in writing, follow the ﬁnal adverse mination procedures in IRM

4 4.81 Tax Exempt Bonds (TEB) Examination Program and Procedures
request. Issue Letter
(DO), Extension of Time for Certain Actions, notify the issuer in writing of the date by which the perfected request must be submitted. (
) After the issuer perfects the appeal request, follow these steps:

Review the request and prepare a rebuttal to the arguments the issuer raised. If no new arguments are raised, notate that in the rebuttal and affirm that our position hasn’t changed. In your rebuttal, address: • Only those statements, facts, or arguments the issuer made that weren’t completely addressed in the
-day letter. • New arguments or facts the issuer raised.

If the protest contains new information or analysis of the issuer’s notify the issuer that the new information submitted may change the case’s outcome and requires further review and possible discussions before you transfer the case ﬁle to Appeals.
Since all unagreed protested cases are subject to TEB Technical mandatory review, request technical assistance before you issue the rebuttal.
You must mail the rebuttal to the issuer, but the issuer is not given an opportunity to respond to the rebuttal.
Completely address all statements, facts, and arguments discussed in the protest, then prepare Letter
, Protest Received to Appeals, and mail to the issuer.
Prepare the case for closing per IRM
, Case Closing Proce- dures for Examiners, and forward to your group manager. (
) Group manager:

Review the case for accuracy and completeness: conﬁrm that the case ﬁle contains a valid protest, adequate rebuttal, printed copies of elec- tronic RCCMS documents, the relevant determination, tax exposure calculation if applicable, adjustment or disallowance letter and Letter
Appeals transfer letter.
Update the case to status
on RCCMS with disposal code
(add ARDI code
for claim denials) and transfer the case to the TEB Technical group responsible for mandatory review.
Ship the paper case ﬁle via Form
to the reviewer identiﬁed by the TEB Technical group manager responsible for mandatory reviews. Note: The TE/GE Closing Group won’t accept any protested case to Appeals with less than
days remaining on the statute (
days for cases Appeals previously returned to the group). Therefore, TEB Technical requires TEB FO to send cases with at least
days remaining on the statute to allow time for mandatory review. (
) The following TEB cases are subject to mandatory review. a. Unagreed exam closures without protest to Appeals requiring issuance a Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency, Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

request. Issue Letter 686 (DO), Extension of Time for Certain Actions, to notify the issuer in writing of the date by which the perfected request must be submitted.

b. Unagreed claim disallowances (full or partial) without protest to requiring the issuance of one of the following: • Letter

M d. Management requests (senior manager’s approval required) (
) The TEB Technical group manager may assign the case for mandatory to the same TLS who initially reviewed the case per IRM

) The mandatory review involves: a. Ensuring that the factual and legal matters documented in the case support the issues raised in the proposed adverse or claim denial. b. Reviewing the issuer’s protest to the Form
-A, Explanation of and the examiner’s rebuttal even if such documentation was reviewed in a prior technical review. (

) If the TLS determines that the examiner’s rebuttal does not sufficiently the issuer’s protest or that the examiner’s position requires further develop- ment, the TLS coordinates with their manager, FO group manager, and the examiner. Once all issues are resolved, the TLS notiﬁes his/her manager, examiner, the examiner’s group manager and transfers the case to Appeals. (

) If the examiner’s group manager decides to transfer the case to Appeals before the TLS determines that the rebuttal sufficiently addresses the protest, the TLS will brief his/her group manager on the case. Then, the program manager, Technical and the FOM discuss whether additional case actions are required before transferring the case to Appeals. (
) Examiner: provide any subsequent revisions to the rebuttal to the issuer the representative before transferring the case to Appeals. (
) Examiner: transfer case to Appeals:
Attach a Form
-A, TE/GE Special Handling Notice, to the paper case ﬁle and mark the checkbox --Forward to Appeals.

Conﬁrm the paper case ﬁle sent to Appeals includes, copies of the following: a. The technical advice memorandum, if any: b. All information received by TEB from the issuer regarding the bond issue or Arbitrage Rebate Claim Denial. c. All workpapers related to TEB’s examination of the bond issue or Arbitrage Rebate Claim Denial. d. TEB’s written Proposed Adverse Determination or Arbitrage Rebate Claim Denial. e. The issuer’s written protest. f. TEB’s response to positions stated by the issuer in its protest.
Ship the paper case ﬁle to Appeals via Form

) Examiner: Close the case on RCCMS in status
with disposal code
the TE/GE Closing Group (
) Examiner: Add a note to the RCCMS Comment box: “Appeals case, DC
). Paper case ﬁle sent directly to Appeals”. (
) If the issuer or authorized representative doesn’t request an administrative appeal of a proposed adverse determination to Appeals, issue the ﬁnal adverse determination letter: Letter
, Notice of Final Adverse mination; Letter
, Final Partial Claim Disallowance; Letter
, Final Claim Disallowance; or Letter
, TEB Arbitrage Claim Notiﬁcation of Adverse Determination, by certiﬁed mail with a request for return receipt. (
) FO group manager forwards a copy of this letter to the Bondholder Coordinator, if applicable. (

) For a conduit ﬁnancing resulting in a ﬁnal adverse determination, whether the conduit borrower is under exam by another operating division another TE/GE function. If the conduit borrower: a. Is under examination, inform the appropriate operating division of the ﬁnal adverse determination and coordinate as needed to consider impact on the conduit borrower’s tax matters. b. Isn’t under examination, refer to the appropriate operating division or other TE/GE function to consider any impact on the borrower’s tax matters. (
) If Appeals settles the case, upon case closing, Appeals sends Form
, Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo and a copy of the closing letter to the Taken program manager, Technical. (

) If Appeals is unable to settle the case, they: a. Issue the Final Adverse Determination Letter and close the case. b. Return the paper case ﬁle to TEB to contact the bondholders (if warranted). Note: However, Appeals doesn’t release Form
jurisdiction back TEB. Accordingly, TEB may not: i) continue any case exam ties, or ii) reengage in resolution actions without reopening the case. (
) If Appeals:

Is under examination, inform the appropriate operating division of the ﬁnal adverse determination and coordinate as needed to consider any impact on the conduit borrower’s tax matters. Isn’t under examination, refer to the appropriate operating division or other TE/GE function to consider any impact on the borrower’s tax matters.

Determines that TEB has not fully developed its position, they: may return the case to TEB for further development or concede the ment’s position and close the case. Receives, during their consideration of the case, a new argument from the issuer, they may return the case to TEB requesting its response to the issuer’s argument. Appeals may or may not release jurisdiction. Releases jurisdiction, TEB is free to re

engage in resolution actions or concede its position and close the case as agreed. Doesn’t release jurisdiction, TEB should provide the response and return the case to Appeals within the established timeframe.
Note: TEB must not communicate with the issuer and/or authorized representative while Appeals has jurisdiction.
